objectives.title: Objectives
objectives.paragraph1: The VOICE project promotes the integration of structured volunteering into the Supported Employment model in Portugal and Romania, creating new employability pathways for people with disabilities or impairments. Volunteering is an effective means for skill development, confidence building, and promoting inclusion and diversity in workplaces and communities. In this context, the project aims to empower people with disabilities or impairments, expanding their role as active participants in society – both as volunteers and valued members of the workforce.
objectives.subTitle: Specific Objectives:
objectives.bullet1: Develop a Resource Kit for Employment-Oriented Volunteering, providing Supported Employment professionals with tools to integrate volunteering into the professional integration process.
objectives.bullet2: Implement a pilot training for 24 professionals, evaluating the effectiveness of structured volunteering in Supported Employment and gathering feedback for improving the approach and resources developed.
objectives.bullet3: Disseminate and valorize the project's resources through multiplier events in each partner country and the creation of a promotional video for social media.

targetGroups.title: Target Groups
targetGroups.paragraph1: The VOICE project promotes the inclusion of people with disabilities or impairments in the labor market through structured volunteering in the context of Supported Employment. To ensure the success of this approach, it involves different target groups:
targetGroups.bullet1: People with disabilities or impairments – The main beneficiaries of the project. VOICE aims to improve the support provided to this audience by strengthening the capacity of Supported Employment professionals to integrate structured volunteering as a strategy for professional inclusion. By promoting this approach, the project will contribute to skill development, confidence building, and improving the employability prospects of people with disabilities or impairments.
targetGroups.bullet2: Supported Employment Professionals – Includes supported employment technicians, vocational counselors, job placement technicians, and other professionals who provide direct support to people with disabilities or impairments. They play an essential role in the professional integration of this audience and will be empowered to integrate structured volunteering into the Supported Employment model, strengthening their intervention and facilitating the transition of beneficiaries to the labor market.
targetGroups.bullet3: Education and Vocational Training Entities (EFP) – Responsible for the training and capacity building of Supported Employment technicians, these entities can integrate the results of the VOICE project to enhance the quality of their programs. The project will provide innovative resources that promote structured volunteering as an essential tool for skill development and professional inclusion within Supported Employment. This approach addresses a gap in current training models.
targetGroups.bullet4: Employers and community organizations – Will be involved in the project to promote inclusive volunteering opportunities and adopt Supported Employment practices, contributing to reducing barriers and fostering diversity in workplaces. With this integrated approach, the VOICE project strengthens the employability of people with disabilities or impairments, promoting a more accessible and equitable society.

activities.title: Activities
activities.paragraph1: The VOICE project is based on three main activities:
activities.bullet1: Development of the Resource Kit for Employment-Oriented Volunteering – Creation of tools and guidelines for Supported Employment professionals, enabling them to integrate volunteering as a strategy for skill development and professional integration.
activities.bullet2: Pilot Training for Supported Employment Professionals – Capacity building for 24 professionals, testing the approach and gathering feedback to optimize the model and resources developed.
activities.bullet3: Dissemination and Exploitation of Results – Organization of multiplier events in Portugal and Romania and production of a promotional video to raise awareness among professionals, employers, and communities about the potential of structured volunteering in professional inclusion.

content.paragraph1: The VOICE project generates concrete impact through the development of strategic resources and dissemination actions that drive the professional inclusion of people with disabilities or impairments.
content.subTitle: Tangible Results
content.bullet1: Brochure – Informative document about the project, its objectives, and main results.
content.bullet2: Website – Digital platform that centralizes information, resources, and project updates.
content.bullet3: Resource Kit for Employment-Oriented Volunteering – Tools and guidelines for Supported Employment professionals, promoting the structured integration of volunteering into employability.
content.bullet4: Pilot Training Sessions – Capacity building for 24 professionals in the implementation of the project's methodology.
content.bullet5: Pilot Activity Report – Detailed evaluation of the training, challenges, and best practices identified.
content.bullet6: Promotional Video – Production of a video to showcase the project's impact, highlighting the role of structured volunteering in professional inclusion.
content.bullet7: Social Media Campaign – Digital communication strategy to promote the promotional video, expanding the project's reach.
content.bullet8: Multiplier Events – Two events, one in Portugal and another in Romania, to present the project's results and encourage the adoption of structured volunteering as a tool for professional inclusion within the Supported Employment model.
content.bullet9: Greater access to structured volunteering for people with disabilities or impairments, promoting their active participation in society and the labor market.
content.bullet10: Strengthening employability and professional skills through practical experiences aligned with market demands.
content.bullet11: Facilitating the transition to paid employment, promoting sustainable career paths.
content.bullet12: Empowering Supported Employment professionals, driving innovative and effective methodologies.
content.bullet13: Greater involvement of employers and communities, encouraging more inclusive recruitment practices.

partners.title: Partners
partners.consultis: Consultis is an organization founded in 2005, based in Vila Nova de Gaia, Portugal, specializing in business consulting, innovation, and supported employment. An active member of the Portuguese Association of Supported Employment, it manages a resource center in Supported Employment in Porto, where it provides support to companies, professionals, and job seekers, particularly disadvantaged groups in the labor market, such as people with disabilities or impairments, youth at risk of exclusion, migrants, and long-term unemployed. In partnership with companies, training entities, educational institutions, social sector organizations, and public entities, Consultis develops solutions tailored to the needs of the labor market, promoting effective strategies for professional and social inclusion. Through consulting, training, and supported employment services, it supports the implementation of more inclusive and sustainable practices, ensuring continuous support for employers and professionals in the labor integration process. Learn more at
partners.pistaMágica: PISTA MÁGICA is the first and only Volunteering School in Portugal, founded in 2008. It operates in volunteering training, creating and implementing programs for organizations, and developing social action projects based on inclusive volunteering. Its mission is to make volunteering accessible and useful to everyone through innovation, empowering volunteers and organizations for more meaningful and sustainable social engagement. Recently, it has expanded its activities to advocacy, influencing public policies to strengthen volunteering as a solution to social challenges. Learn more at
partners.hao: Health Action Overseas Romania (HAO) is a non-governmental organization active in Romania since 1991, specializing in providing community social services for children and young people with disabilities in Constanța, Galați, and Bucharest. Initially focused on supporting children with severe disabilities in orphanages, it expanded its intervention to educational and therapeutic programs, supported residences, community development, rights advocacy, and family support. HAO provides Supported Employment services for young adults with disabilities and operates in the field of education and vocational training (VET), developing capacity-building programs that promote social, civic, and professional skills. Its training offer includes the qualification of professionals involved in the socio-professional inclusion of people with disabilities, ensuring the application of effective and person-centered methodologies. Based on the Social Model of Disability, it promotes capacity for independent living and professional integration, ensuring sustainable inclusion in the labor market. Learn more at

news.title: News
news.subTitle: VOICE Project kicks off activities with first transnational meeting in Porto
news.paragraph1: The VOICE project – Volunteering Opportunities for Inclusion and Competence Development of Disabled Individuals within Supported Employment (2024-2-PT01-KA210-VET-000270713) held its first transnational meeting on March 6, 2025, in Porto, Portugal.
news.paragraph2: Organized by Consultis, the coordinating entity, the event brought together partners from Portugal and Romania to structure the implementation of structured volunteering in the Supported Employment model.
news.paragraph3: The meeting focused on analyzing the employability challenges of people with disabilities or impairments and the potential of volunteering for skill development, confidence building, and professional inclusion. The project's objectives, work plan, and strategies to ensure the effectiveness of the methodologies to be developed were also discussed.
news.paragraph4: Co-financed by the Erasmus+ program, the VOICE project will run until June 30, 2026. Over 18 months, it will develop and test innovative resources to strengthen professional inclusion, empowering Supported Employment professionals to integrate structured volunteering into their practices.
news.paragraph5: The meeting, held at the Supported Employment Resource Center of Consultis, marked the official start of activities and strengthened cooperation among partners. Follow us for more updates on the progress and impact of VOICE.
